metadata.title: GPT-Load - High-Performance AI API Load Balancer
metadata.description: Enterprise-grade AI API transparent proxy service that preserves native API formats of AI service providers. Provides key rotation, multi-group management, load balancing for stable and reliable AI application proxy services.
metadata.keywords: GPT, OpenAI, API, transparent proxy, load balancing, key rotation, Go, high performance

header.title: Intelligent Key Management
header.description: GPT-Load uses an intelligent key management mechanism to ensure high availability and stability through polling load balancing, automatic fault detection, and recovery.

goal.title: Goal
goal.description: Achieve fair load balancing of requests among multiple keys within a group.

items.title: Atomic Counter
items.description: Ensures polling consistency and fairness under high concurrency

items.title: Status Filtering
items.description: Polling is limited to keys with an 'active' status within the group

trigger.title: Trigger Scenarios
trigger.description: Automatically triggered on request failure (HTTP Status ≥ 400 or network error)

steps.title: Mark as Failed
steps.description: Increment the failure count for the current failed key

steps.title: Get New Key
steps.description: Immediately fetch the next available key in the group via polling

steps.title: Seamless Retry
steps.description: Retry the request with the new key, transparent to the client

steps.title: Retry Limit
steps.description: Configured maximum retry attempts. Returns final error to the client if all attempts fail

trigger.title: Trigger Condition
trigger.description: When a key's cumulative failure count reaches the blacklist threshold

action.title: Action
items: Removed from the polling queue, no new requests

trigger.title: Trigger Time
trigger.description: A background cron job runs periodically at the key validation interval

steps.title: Health Check
steps.description: Request a validation endpoint (e.g., models list) using the blacklisted key

steps.title: Validation Success
steps.description:
• Key status is restored to 'active'
• Failure count is reset to 0
• Re-added to the polling queue

steps.title: Validation Failure
steps.description: Remains 'invalid', waiting for the next check cycle

items.title: Load Balancing
items.description: Atomic counter ensures fair polling under high concurrency

items.title: Automatic Recovery
items.description: Periodic health checks for automatic fault recovery

items.title: Fault Isolation
items.description: Quickly identifies faulty keys to ensure service stability

performancePage.title: Performance Details - GPT-Load
performancePage.description: Learn how GPT-Load achieves ultimate performance through zero I/O operations, zero-copy streaming, and lock-free concurrency.

header.title: Performance Details
header.description: GPT-Load adopts a “proxy path first” high-performance design philosophy, with all optimizations aimed at ensuring the ultimate performance and stability of core proxy requests.

features.title: Zero I/O Operations
features.description: Proxy requests are fully processed in memory

proxyPerformance.title: Ultimate Proxy Request Performance
proxyPerformance.zeroIoNote: To achieve the lowest latency and highest concurrency, the core path of proxy requests is designed for “zero I/O operations”.

inMemory.title: In-Memory Service
inMemory.description: All data required for routing and decision-making, including group configurations and key information, is preloaded into memory on service startup and configuration changes. No database or disk access is needed during proxy requests.

mechanism.title: Real-time Passthrough Mechanism
mechanism.description: GPT-Load uses a real-time passthrough mode, directly connecting the upstream service's data stream (io.Reader) to the client response (io.Writer), without any intermediate buffering, line-by-line reading, or content parsing.

gptload.title: ✅ GPT-Load Way
gptload.description: Upstream data stream → Direct passthrough → Client

advantages.title: Avoids Packet Truncation
advantages.description: Does not break original data packet structure by reading line-by-line

advantages.title: Ultimate Compatibility
advantages.description: Natively supports all data formats like SSE, JSON streaming, and binary

advantages.title: Unlimited Response Capability
advantages.description: Theoretically handles any size of upstream response data

advantages.title: Zero Latency Transmission
advantages.description: Data is forwarded upon arrival, with no buffering delay

advantages.title: Extremely Low Memory Usage
advantages.description: Memory usage is independent of response size as data is not cached

advantages.title: Native Performance Experience
advantages.description: Response speed is nearly identical to the native performance of the upstream service

asyncLogging.title: Asynchronous Logging
asyncLogging.description: Request logs are written using a delayed asynchronous strategy, completely decoupled from the request-response lifecycle to ensure that logging operations do not interfere with real-time proxy performance.

httpClient.title: Efficient HTTP Client Reuse
items: Maintains independent, reusable HTTP client instances with underlying connection pooling for each group
When group settings (like timeout) change, the system dynamically creates a new client instance in real-time to ensure immediate application of the new configuration

atomicLockFree.title: Atomic Operations & Lock-Free Design
atomicLockFree.description: In high-frequency concurrent operations like key polling counts, the sync/atomic package is used for lock-free programming, avoiding the performance overhead of mutexes.

mechanism.title: Mechanism
mechanism.description: Operations like adding and validating keys are executed as asynchronous background tasks.

advantage.title: Advantage
advantage.description: This allows management operations not to block the service, theoretically enabling the system to manage millions of keys.

architecture.title: Architecture
architecture.description: Supports horizontal scaling with a multi-node Master-Slave architecture.

sync.title: Synchronization
items: Configuration changes on the master node are pushed as notifications via Redis Pub/Sub
Slave nodes listen for and pull updates through the built-in configuration synchronizer, achieving eventual consistency of configurations across the cluster

lowUsage.title: Extremely Low Resource Usage
lowUsage.description: Thanks to Go's efficient memory management and the performance optimizations mentioned above (e.g., zero-copy, connection pooling), GPT-Load runs as a compiled binary with no extra runtime dependencies, achieving extremely low resource usage.

wideApplicability.title: Wide Applicability
wideApplicability.description: In typical standalone deployments, it requires low CPU and memory to ensure smooth service operation.
items: Handles high-concurrency scenarios for large enterprises
Suitable for individual developers with limited resources

quickStartPage.title: Quick Start
quickStartPage.description: Follow these steps to quickly start and run GPT-Load.

lightweightDeployment.title: Lightweight Deployment
lightweightDeployment.description: Uses SQLite database and in-memory storage, ideal for personal use and quick trials

prerequisites.title: Prerequisites
items: At least 128MB RAM and 1GB disk space

securityWarning.title: Important Security Notice
securityWarning.body: You MUST change the default admin key before deployment!
rules: Use a complex key of at least 20 characters
Include uppercase, lowercase, numbers, and special characters
NEVER use default or simple keys like sk-123456
Using a weak key in production poses a serious security risk

steps.title: Create a Working Directory
steps.command:
# Create directory and enter
mkdir -p gpt-load && cd gpt-load

steps.title: Download Configuration Files
steps.command:
# Download Docker Compose config
wget https://raw.githubusercontent.com/tbphp/gpt-load/refs/heads/main/docker-compose.yml

# Download environment variables config
wget -O .env https://raw.githubusercontent.com/tbphp/gpt-load/refs/heads/main/.env.example

securityConfig.title: Update Security Config Immediately
securityConfig.line1: Edit the .env file, and change the following:

steps.title: Start the Service
steps.command:
# Start the GPT-Load service
docker compose up -d

steps.title: Verify Deployment
steps.loginNote: Log in to the admin interface using the AUTH_KEY you set in the .env file

commands.title: Restart Service
commands.command: docker compose down && docker compose up -d

commands.title: Update Version
commands.command: docker compose pull && docker compose down && docker compose up -d

nextSteps.text: Want more deployment options, like using MySQL/PostgreSQL or setting up a cluster? Check out the full Deployment Guide.

header.title: Cluster Deployment
header.description: GPT-Load high-availability cluster deployment solution, supporting master-slave architecture and horizontal scaling.

banner.title: Enterprise-Grade High-Availability Architecture
banner.description: Designed for large-scale production environments to ensure service stability and reliability.

items.title: Master-Slave Architecture
items.description: Master node election and configuration synchronization based on Redis

items.title: Horizontal Scaling
items.description: Stateless slave node design supports dynamic scaling

items.title: Data Sharing
items.description: Unified data storage and caching with MySQL + Redis

importantNote.title: Important Note
importantNote.description: In a production environment, it is strongly recommended to use independent, high-availability MySQL and Redis services.

requirements.title: Infrastructure
items: Servers: At least 2 (1 master, 1 slave); 3+ recommended for higher availability
Network: Ensure low-latency network connectivity between all nodes

requirements.title: Dependent Services
items: Redis: Version 6.2+; for caching, distributed locks, and message queue

sections.title: Environment Variable Configuration
sections.content: Make the following core configurations in the master node's .env file:
sections.code:
IS_SLAVE=false
REDIS_HOST=your-redis-host
REDIS_PORT=6379
REDIS_PASSWORD=your-redis-password
DB_HOST=your-mysql-host
DB_PORT=3306
DB_USER=your-mysql-user
DB_PASSWORD=your-mysql-password
DB_NAME=gpt_load

sections.title: Environment Variable Configuration
sections.content: In the .env files of all slave nodes, ensure IS_SLAVE=true and use the same database and Redis configuration as the master node.
sections.code:
IS_SLAVE=true
REDIS_HOST=your-redis-host
# ... other configurations are the same as the master node

sections.title: Startup Order
sections.content: Always start the master node first. Wait for it to fully initialize before starting all slave nodes.
sections.note: Slave nodes will automatically connect to Redis on startup and synchronize the latest configuration from the master node via the Pub/Sub mechanism.

healthCheck.title: Health Check
clusterMonitoring: Monitor cluster metrics with Prometheus + Grafana
View all node statuses in the master node's admin interface
Configure alerting rules to detect anomalies promptly

items.title: Horizontal Scaling
items: Add new node: Configure as a slave and start it
Remove node: Simply shut down the slave node service

items.title: Master Node Migration
items: Shut down the old master node
Change a slave node's configuration to IS_SLAVE=false
Restart the node to make it the new master

practices.title: Recommended Practices
items: Use external, high-availability database and Redis services
Configure a load balancer (e.g., Nginx) for the GPT-Load cluster
Regularly back up the database and configuration files
Monitor Redis connection count and memory usage

practices.title: Practices to Avoid
items: Performing write operations on multiple nodes simultaneously
Starting slave nodes before the master node is fully initialized
Using the default AUTH_KEY in a production environment
Neglecting to monitor the database and Redis

features.title: Core Technical Features
features.subtitle: Enterprise-grade architecture design, optimized for production environments

items.title: High-Performance Architecture
items.description: Developed with Go 1.23+, featuring zero-copy streaming and a coroutine concurrency model for high-concurrency handling.

items.title: Transparent Proxy
items.description: Fully preserves native API formats, allowing seamless integration with various AI services without code modification.

items.title: Intelligent Key Management
items.description: Group management, dynamic rotation, and automatic retries ensure high service availability.

items.title: Load Balancing
items.description: Multi-upstream support, weight configuration, and health checks for intelligent routing to available nodes.

items.title: Hot-Reload Configuration
items.description: A three-tiered configuration system (environment variables, system settings, group settings) supports hot updates.
items.technical: Environment Variables → System Settings → Group Settings

items.title: Cluster Support
items.description: Master-slave architecture with a stateless design supports horizontal scaling and distributed deployment.

items.title: Security Mechanisms
items.description: Bearer Token authentication, group isolation, request logging, and sensitive information redaction.

items.title: Admin Backend
items.description: A modern interface with Vue 3 for real-time monitoring, log viewing, and configuration management.

items.title: Developer-Friendly
items.description: Complete RESTful API, detailed documentation, and one-click deployment with Docker.

highlight.title: Production-Ready Enterprise Architecture
highlight.description: From standalone deployment to a distributed cluster, from development to production, GPT-Load provides a complete solution.

metadata.title: Routing Strategy - GPT-Load
metadata.description: Understand GPT-Load's path handling mechanism to master flexible path configuration and ensure correct client-upstream connections.

header.title: Routing Strategy
header.description: Understand GPT-Load's path handling mechanism to master flexible path configuration and ensure correct client-upstream connections.

principle.title: Passthrough Principle
principle.description: GPT-Load follows a passthrough principle, only responsible for path replacement to maintain maximum flexibility. The core logic is to replace the proxy prefix in the client request with the actual upstream address.

configExamples.title: Configuration Examples
configExamples.description: Using OpenRouter as an example (full path: {code}), with group name {code} and channel type {code}:

clientConfig.title: Client Config
clientConfig.note: Note: Must end with a / to prevent the client from automatically appending the v1 path

practices.title: Configuration Advice
recommendations: Recommend using Config Method 2 for a clear and understandable structure
First, determine the full upstream API address
Choose the appropriate path split point based on client characteristics
Maintain consistency and maintainability in your configuration

practices.title: Debugging Tips
recommendations: Check GPT-Load request logs to confirm the upstream address
Use the test path to verify the correctness of the configuration
Pay attention to the client's path concatenation rules
Flexibly adjust the configuration to adapt to different scenarios

summary.title: Configuration Summary
summary.description: Understanding the path handling logic is key: GPT-Load is only responsible for simple string replacement, and its flexible configuration can adapt to various client and upstream service needs.
summary.corePrinciple: Core Principle: Ensure that after being proxied by GPT-Load, the final upstream address for {code} and {code} is correct.
